data.name: Eastern Bluebird
data.food: Berries, fruit, spiders, beetles, caterpillars, grasshoppers, crickets
data.habitat: Open grassy areas, parks, backyards, farmlands, woodlands
funfacts: Females are duller and grayer
Females build nest and incubate eggs
Nest in tree cavities or nest boxes
Attracted to mealworms and shelled sunflower seeds at feeder
Enjoy birdbaths

data.name: Northern Cardinal
data.food: Fruit, seeds, beetles, crickets, spiders, flies, moths, cicadas
funfacts: State bird of N.C. and six other states
Males (red) and females (brown) have same red beak
Can crack hard seeds with large bill
Often seen feeding female in early spring
Go bald as part of molting cycle

data.name: Carolina Chickadee
data.food: Insects, fruit, seeds, spiders
funfacts: May nest in tree cavity or bird house
Fly to a feeder, grab a seed, and then carry it to a branch
Will eat upside down clinging to a branch
Call is a high fast “chicka-dee-dee-dee”
Live in flocks of up to 8 birds in winter

data.name: American Crow
data.food: Insects, small animals, fruit, nuts, garbage
data.habitat: Open areas with access to trees
funfacts: Often mate for life
Are among the most intelligent birds
Inquisitive and good problem solvers
Able to hide food in many places and remember location
May form flocks in the thousands

data.name: Mourning Dove
data.food: Grains, peanuts, millet, berries, seeds of wild grasses and weeds
funfacts: Named for mournful call
May nest in gutters or eaves of houses
Feed their chicks “crop milk,” a milky substance produced in their crop
Frequently found perched on telephone wires
Unusual in that they drink by sucking up water

data.name: Bald Eagle
data.food: Primarily fish; also birds, reptiles, crabs, rabbits, muskrats
data.habitat: Forests, near large bodies of water
funfacts: U.S. national bird
Steal food from ospreys
Prefer tall trees with wide view
Nest is 2 to 4 feet tall and 5 to 6 feet in diameter
Once on endangered species list, have made a comeback due to protection of habitat and banning of the pesticide DDT

data.name: House Finch
data.food: Seeds, buds, millet, fruit
data.habitat: Wooded areas, farmlands, lawns, parks, backyards
funfacts: Males may have red, orange, or yellow breast
Color of males derived from diet
Females are brown
Like nesting in hanging flower baskets
Highly social birds, often seen in flocks

data.name: American Goldfinch
data.food: Seeds from grasses, flowers, thistles, and trees
funfacts: Males bright yellow only in the spring and summer
After molting in the fall, males and females look similar
Attracted to Black-eyed Susans and coneflowers
Especially fond of nyjer seeds
Appear roller-coaster like in flight

data.name: Canada Goose
data.food: Grasses, agricultural grains, berries, aquatic plants
data.habitat: Near water, grassy fields, grain fields
funfacts: Female is called goose, male a gander, babies goslings
Have a wingspan of 4.2 to 5.6 feet
Like open fields so they can easily see predators
Fly in large groups in a V-formation
Can be heard honking in flight

data.name: Common Grackle
data.food: Fish, worms, seeds, garbage, corn, other crops
data.habitat: Farms, parks, backyards, woodlands, meadows, marshes
funfacts: May sit in groups atop trees and telephone poles
Walk on lawns and fields making raucous chatter
Number one threat to cornfields
Sometimes nest in groups of 75 or more pairs

data.name: Red-shouldered Hawk
data.food: Mice, frogs, snakes, lizards, toads, crayfish
funfacts: Both males and females build the nest
Often reuse last year’s nest
Call a repetitive “kee-aah”
Often seen soaring, searching for prey
Stay in same territory for many years

data.name: Great Blue Heron
data.food: Mostly fish; also frogs, salamanders, turtles, snakes, insects, rodents
data.habitat: Marshes, swamps, flooded fields, ditches, lake edges
funfacts: Can hunt food both day and night
Swallow their prey whole
Can choke to death if prey too large
Wingspan can be up to 6.5 feet
Despite large size, weigh only 5 to 6 pounds

data.name: Ruby-throated Hummingbird
data.food: Insects; nectar of tubular flowers, especially orange or red
data.habitat: Woodlands, meadows, orchards, backyards, stream borders
funfacts: Nest is size of thimble and may include spider webs
Weigh eighth of an ounce
Beat wings 53 times a second
Can fly backwards
Short legs prevent walking or hopping
Migrate across the Gulf of Mexico

data.name: Blue Jay
data.food: Insects, nuts, seeds, greens, small vertebrates
funfacts: Prefer tray feeders to hanging feeders
Spread oak trees through fondness for acorns
Known for family bonds and intelligence
Can imitate call of Red-shouldered Hawk
The higher its crest is raised, the more agitated it is

data.name: Dark-eyed Junco
data.food: Mostly seeds and insects
funfacts: Usually hop along the ground looking for seeds
Females tend to migrate farther south than males
Often called snowbirds
Travel in flocks in the winter
Often called snowbirds
Only found in Davidson in the winter

data.name: Mallard
data.food: Plants, worms, snails, insect larvae, seeds
funfacts: Estimated to be the world’s most abundant duck
Males have green heads, females have brown
Find food by tipping head underwater and tail in the air
Only females quack; males make a quiet rasping call
Ducklings can leave the nest within a day, swim, and feed themselves

data.name: Northern Mockingbird
data.food: Berries, beetles, earthworms, moths, ants, bees, grasshoppers
funfacts: Imitate whistles, alarms, and songs of other birds
May sing continuously at night as well as in the day
Males may learn up to 200 songs
Aggressively chase off intruders to their territory
Winter territories are centered on berry bushes

data.name: Brown-headed Nuthatch
data.food: Insects, pine seeds
funfacts: Sound like a rubber duckie when vocalizing
Live in family groups; last year’s young may care for this year’s chicks
Unlike most birds, can use tools to pry away tree bark to obtain insects
Often walk headfirst down tree-trunks
Declining, due to loss of trees needed for nest cavities
Will nest in bird boxes if you provide a 1⅛ inch hole

data.name: American Robin
data.food: Fruit, berries, caterpillars, earthworms, snails, insects
data.habitat: Woodlands, fields, backyards, parks, lawns, forests
funfacts: Reddish-orange chest, blue eggs
Listen, rather than look, for worms on lawns and
Vulnerable to pesticide poisoning on lawns
Playful song says “cheerily, cheer up, cheer up, cheerily, cheer up”
Like birdbaths and sprinklers

data.name: Song Sparrow
data.food: Seeds, fruit, beetles, caterpillars, grasshoppers, earthworms, spiders
data.habitat: Marshes, farmlands, lake edges, woodlands, backyards, forests
funfacts: May nest close to houses, in shrubs, or flower beds
Return to a similar area each year, defending their territory by singing
Males sing from exposed perches
Repeat their clear song every couple of minutes
Rarely flock together

data.name: White-throated Sparrow
data.food: Seeds, insects, berries
funfacts: Have two color forms: white-head stripes or tan-head stripes
White-head striped birds are more aggressive
Individuals almost always mate with a bird of opposite color form
Known for their clear whistle song, even at night
Only found in Davidson in the winter

data.name: Brown Thrasher
data.food: Mostly insects, some fruit, seeds
funfacts: Sing from exposed perches at the top of trees
Mimic other bird calls
Know more than 1,000 songs
Feed by thrashing through leaf litter to find food
Aggressively defend nest

data.name: Tufted Titmouse
data.food: Seeds, nuts, berries, caterpillars, beetles, ants, wasps, spiders, snails
funfacts: Frequent visitor to feeders
Store seeds in bark crevices during fall and winter
Use nest holes and cavities left by woodpeckers
Young often remain with parents throughout their first winter
Can use their feet to hold seeds while breaking them open

data.name: Eastern Towhee
data.food: Mostly insects, seeds, berries
funfacts: Males (pictured) have a black head, upper body, and tail
Females have brown head, upper body, and tail
Song is a short “drink your teeeeea” or says “chewink”
Kick back both feet in the leaves when looking for food
Often victim of parasitic cowbirds that lay eggs in other birds’ nests

data.name: Black & Turkey Vultures
data.food: Dead animals, preferably fresh
data.habitat: Roost in wooded areas, forage over open fields, roadsides, landfills
funfacts: Black vultures have black heads; Turkey vultures have red heads
Turkey vultures one of few birds that use sense of smell to find food
Black vultures lack a good sense of smell and often follow turkey vultures
Have stomach acid strong enough to eat rotting meat that would make us sick
Important to our ecosystem, removing diseased and decaying animals

data.name: Downy Woodpecker
data.food: Insects, berries, acorns, grains
funfacts: Most likely woodpecker species to visit backyard feeder
Help trees by feeding on harmful insects
Drum on wood instead of singing
May forage in mixed-species flocks
Attracted to suet, sunflower seeds, and peanuts at feeder

data.name: Red-bellied Woodpecker
data.food: Insects, acorns, fruit, spiders, nuts, pinecone seeds
funfacts: Can extend tongue 2 inches past beak to snatch prey from deep crevices
Drum on wood to claim territory
Red belly often faint and hard to see
Hammer acorns and berries into tree crevices for winter food
Attracted to suet, sunflower seeds, and peanuts at feeder

data.name: Carolina Wren
data.food: Fruit, seeds, spiders, caterpillars, moths, beetles, crickets
data.habitat: Backyards, swampy areas, farmlands, wooded areas
funfacts: May nest in discarded flower pots and mailboxes
Males build multiple nests; females choose nest
Song a loud repetitive “teakettle-teakettle”
Unlike most songbirds, male and female defend a year-round territory
Often cock their tail upward when looking for food, down when singing
